Today, I'm reiterating my concerns and urging @SecCardona, @UsEdGov, and @POTUS to reconsider their stance, and grant waivers to all 50 states to forego federal standardized testing for this academic year.

Students, many of whom haven't had access to the necessary hardware to learn effectively from home, have undergone a year of trauma.

This turbulent time calls on us to think creatively about how we can assist in their growth. Standardized tests are not conducive to that goal.

The #AmericanRescuePlan provides $130 billion to support school re-openings. 

That aid must be focused on our students' holistic wellbeing. Using this investment to resource a one-size-fits-all, testing-forward approach would leave our children even further behind.

Earlier this month, I wrote to @SecCardona imploring him to grant waivers allowing states to bypass federal standardized testing.

The harms associated with standardized testing will only be compounded by a year of often-interrupted, remote learning. https://twitter.com/RepBowman/status/1369292196369825792 QT @RepBowman This morning, I was joined by colleagues in writing to @SecCardona, urging him to provide all 50 states with standardized testing waivers for this academic year.

Our READ Act makes clear that we‚Äôre fighting to make sure every child learns how to read, and consequently, can find success in their education and livelihoods. 8/8
We need aggressive action to combat the literacy crisis in our country, and as someone with a background in early childhood literacy, I‚Äôm proud to lead the charge. /7

And the implications stretch beyond education. Over $200 million in health care costs is linked to illiteracy each year: when individuals can‚Äôt understand their prescription bottle, how can we expect them to stay healthy? /6

Prior to serving in Congress, I was a chemistry teacher in north Philadelphia to 11th grade students. Chemistry is already a complicated subject, but it‚Äôs made all the more difficult if you are reading at a 3rd or 4th grade level, as many of my students were. /5

As we work to get kids safely back in school, one of our first priorities needs to be addressing any loss of learning, particularly around literacy. What people must remember is that without literacy, learning other subjects becomes nearly impossible. /4

For years, the data has been clear: "A student who can‚Äôt read on grade level by 3rd grade is four times less likely to graduate by age 19 than a child who does read proficiently by that time." /3 https://www.edweek.org/teaching-learning/study-third-grade-reading-predicts-later-high-school-graduation/2011/04

The need for this legislation during this COVID crisis cannot be overstated. We are seeing early childhood literacy rates drop in PA and across the country. /2

https://whyy.org/articles/half-a-million-pa-kids-are-supposed-to-be-learning-to-read-right-now-are-they/

This from the Atlanta Fed compares wage groups from the bottom 25% (blue) of wage earners to the top 25% (red).

The income gap is getting narrower and has been for a while. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwxElAoWgAU56JE.jpg

Should we really consider us in a crisis of income inequality when the situation has been trending better for ten years, and recently at an accelerated pace?

RT @SenatorMenendez üö®BREAKINGüö® @NydiaVelazquez, @RepAOC & I are introducing the Puerto Rico Self-Determination Act.
 
The #PRSDA would provide the people of Puerto Rico with an inclusive & democratic process to determine their own political future. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwxzKB1WUAYz34i.jpg

In 1787, the founders of this country met to form a constitutional convention to decide how America ought to be governed. Now, 123 years after the U.S. government invaded Puerto Rico, we must ask the people of the Island the same question.
And I am proud that we are introducing it with over 70 co-sponsors, and I am confident that even more Members of Congress will join on in coming weeks.

After over one hundred years of colonial rule, Puerto Ricans would have a mechanism to determine their own future. 

This bill introduced just now would provide a democratic option by giving the Puerto Rican people a chance to make their voices heard in two open elections. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ewx_tRZXEAUkQq3.jpg

What actions do I need to take now? 

Other than filing your 2021 taxes to ensure the IRS has your up to date family information, no action is needed at this time. Keep an eye out for more information later this year on how the monthly delivery will work.

How long will these payments be made for? 

This credit is currently only for 2021, but I‚Äôm fighting to make them permanent!

Who qualifies for this credit? 

Individuals who make up to $75,000 a year or joint filers making up to $150,000 a year qualify for the tax credit. From there, the funds will be reduced by 50 dollars for every additional one thousand dollars of gross income.

How will this credit be delivered? 

For the first time, a portion of the credit will be delivered monthly, beginning in the second half of this year. Families will receive the rest when filing 2021 taxes in 2022.

How much will qualifying families receive? 

Families with children under 6 will receive an increased credit, totaling $3,600 per child. Families with children ages 6-17 will receive a total credit of $3K per child.   Family income can no longer be too low to receive the credit.

RT @repdinatitus I‚Äôm proud to chair the first hearing of my subcommittee in the 117th Congress on the importance of investing in resilient infrastructure. https://twitter.com/TransportDems/status/1372610720886628359 QT @TransportDems Data shows hurricanes, tornadoes, floods, wildfires, abnormal heatwaves, and freezes are happening more frequently. 

Today's @TransportDems hearing will examine how #BuildingSmarter will reduce the impact of these events on tens of millions of Americans. https://youtu.be/Fy-NaJkap70

@bldgsciences: 65% of U.S. counties, cities, and towns have yet to adopt modern building codes. Upgrading to modern standards could save hundreds of millions of dollars in disaster response and recovery costs by making communities more resilient to floods/high winds/earthquakes.

Several reform efforts were authorized in the wake of Hurricane Katrina, including the creation of the National Mitigation Framework, which focuses on a community approach to mitigation/resilience. Its goal is to reduce the impacts of disasters, especially the loss of life.

In 2018, the Disaster Recovery Reform Act provided extra help for communities to prepare for and deal with disasters. DRRA also incentivizes states to invest in #BuildingSmarter to prevent deaths and curb the rising costs of disasters.

@TransportDems have worked to enact reforms and enhancements to the Stafford Act to bolster Federal assistance through @fema to State, local, tribal, and territorial governments and to invest in #BuildingSmarter infrastructure.

As natural disasters become more frequent, T&I has worked to equip @fema with the tools and funding it needs to mitigate and respond to these events.
